Trial_Design.evidence: Randomized clinical trial in a simulation setting.

Participants.evidence: Surgical teams consisted of 1 surgeon and 2 nurses from a surgical ward from 4 different hospitals in Amsterdam, the Netherlands.

Intervention.evidence: The teams were randomized to manage 3 simulated deteriorating patient scenarios with or without the use of cognitive aids.

Objective.evidence: To test the effectiveness of cognitive aids on adherence to best practice in the management of deteriorating postoperative surgical ward patients.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome of the study was failure to adhere to best practice, expressed as the percentage of omitted critical management steps.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Twenty-five surgical teams performed 75 patient scenarios with cognitive aids, and 25 teams performed 75 patient scenarios without cognitive aids.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Using the cognitive aids resulted in a reduction of omitted critical management steps from 33% to 10%, which is a 70% ( P < .001) reduction. This effect remained significant (odds ratio, 0.63; 95% CI, −0.228 to −0.061; P = .001) in a multivariate analysis.
